各位大英帝國做緊嘢／將會做嘢嘅巴絲打，歡迎入嚟呢到鳩噏扮下工

Q&A credit to 滑蛋豬仔飯

Q: 如果無BC又想係英國打工係咪好難?

A:
通常會比working visa一係大公司
D細公司仔都見過有批不過當然會少D

老老實實渣BNO/特區係就係難D不過都唔係無可能
都識得有人搞得掂個visa
以前有同學會係cv度寫明話要working visa
如果間公司都肯in你既話多數即係肯批
唔洗浪費大家時間
大小公司都有 試下無妨

再唔係學其他巴打講
申請左working holiday做住先都未嘗不可
當然之後整唔整到tier 2 working visa就唔敢講
不過起碼都有2年比你係度做下野儲下經驗先

如果做開比較專業行業既朋友其實拎左working holiday visa先，再轉tier 2既機會都幾樂觀，都識幾個朋友都係咁，好似都係做design / I.T.之類 (by 賽麗娜Serena)


Q: 想問下英國見工係咪同香港一樣都係上網報?

A:
如果你話搵工過程其實同香港差唔多
睇你咩工啦
普通黎講大公司既話都係cv cover letter -> online test -> phone in-> assessment centre ( 可以好多round) -> final in
細公司就少幾個步驟咁


Q: 想問下係咪bno 同特區都可以fg 一年tier5 先，唔洗特登要搵肯比tier2 既公司住

A:
你英國畢業定香港想過去？ 唔係英國畢業唔肯定當地申請有無唔同但BNO 隨時可以申請tier 5 重有兩年，特區要抽架，都係兩年。
當地申請可能短d , 我當初因爲公司未令到可以簽visa 既licence 就幫我申請住tier 5 先，得特區又過左抽籤所以係visa 公司幫我係英國申請，但咁就得一年.. 無深究點解。
但全部香港申請過去既都有兩年。 (by 花生哥)

Q: 下年打算去working holiday 會唔會好難搵工同搵地方住（想住反係zoom1,2) 聽人講就話最好係香港搵定先去係好定唔好 我就做開酒吧個邊會唔會香港人 真心求教

A:
英國bar tender既需求量其實好大 因為佢pub既數量基本上同香港7仔有得揮 甚至係正常既餐廳入面都會有間pub仔/bar比人淨飲野吹水
所以你有經驗根本唔洗驚 去到英國任何一個地方都一定搵到野做

講我自己經驗啦 我就做好typical既西餐廳既 入面全部鬼佬
因為要升supervisor 所以gm要求我識哂餐廳所有部份 包括floor hatch同bar
Bar嗰邊我完全係一張白紙 連用咖啡機都唔識 基本上淨係識開水喉倒果汁呢d白痴都識做既野
去到依家講緊一個在既時間 叫做忙起上黎可以打哂三邊 聽日冇人返比人編左去自己睇bar

我覺得做bar最緊要係識同客吹水 尤其係餐廳bar
好似我地咁 係住宅區 長期都有熟客日日黎打"等" 真係日日風雨不改黎報到
黎到冇野做咪同bar tender吹水囉 所以你一定要好吹得

其餘都冇乜野擔心 驚咪去indeed search下囉 一大炸請緊人 (by 小野屋杏)

Q: 英國黎緊暑假畢業，準備搵工 （宜家4月中係咪太遲)

A: 唔遲
雖然有啲係截左
但仲有好多
留學生有優勢 就係唔怕relocation
成個英國既工你都apply得
宜家真係開始send cv都唔會太遲既
好多大公司如果唔係grad scheme既話其實一路都請緊人
以前好多同學都係8/9月先有offer
有D直頭下年1月先有工開
所以唔洗擔心既肯踏出第一步搵工就ok (by 馬壯FN2)

If you are getting an UK Tier 2 (Work Permit) visa and have British National (Overseas) status, you should get your UK Tier 2 visa using your BN(O) passport. This is because -

1) BN(O) passport holders with a long term UK visa do not need to register with the local police while HKSAR passport holders, as Chinese nationals, are required to register with the local police.

2) BN(O) passport holders with long term UK visas are treated as Commonwealth citizens in the UK. He/She can register to vote in all UK elections. HKSAR passport holders cannot register to vote in any UK elections. Being on the electoral roll helps you to build up your own credit history in the UK.

3) BN(O) passport holders can apply for British civil service jobs open to Commonwealth citizens once he/she has Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) while HKSAR passport holders cannot apply for British civil service jobs until he/she has become a British Citizen.

4) BN(O) passport holders can apply for registration to become a British Citizen using form B(OTA), this is a cheaper method than naturalisation. HKSAR passport holder must naturalise in order to get British Citizenship.

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/application-to-register-as-a-british-citizen-form-bota

In the UK, leisure services are usually run by local government (local councils), not central government (Westminster). Although a lot of local government funding comes from central government, but local councils do received income from people living in their area via the council tax (or rates as it used to be called).

If you live in a flat in the centre of Manchester, you will need to pay council tax to Manchester City Council. While there is no way the local council can work out whether users of its leisure facilities paid council tax in the local area, but it is highly unlikely that someone who live in Manchester will regularly uses leisure facilities in Glasgow and vice versa.

so apparently uk could have limited the level of eu migration to a lower level by implementing existing eu rules on free movement and kick people out who can't get a job in like 3 months or something - the question is which UK government department will deal with this one? EEA nationals living in the UK do not need to register with any UK government department unless they want to work. Unlike in mainland Europe where any EEA nationals need to register with the local town hall, the UK does not operate such a civil household registration system (戶籍制度). Another important point is cost - who is going to pay for it all? Local government or Central government?

kick people out who can't get a job in like 3 months or something - these people will just come back in the next LCC flight!

The UK benefit and health service system differs from most mainland EU countries. The Labour welfare and health service reforms after 1945 were influenced by the Beveridge Report which suggested a cradle to grave social security system in the UK after WW2.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/bitesize/intermediate2/history/cradle_to_the_grave/welfare_state/revision/1/

The Labour reforms post 1945 were based on -

1) free at the point of need
2) universal provision for all
3) comprehensive in that it covers all types of need.

uk can also impose extra rules like other countries on claiming benefits but they didn't do that either for some weird reasons - since EU law does not allow member states to discriminate other EEA nationals within the country, thus the post 1945 UK welfare state needs to treat UK and EEA nationals equally. If it is universal (like child benefit) for British Citizens in the UK, it also needs to be universal for EEA nationals in the UK. This means that for example, the UK NHS cannot charge EEA patients unless it also charges British Citizens for health care. The post war welfare state is so sacred in the UK that even Mrs T was unable to move it towards the insurance system that most European countries operate in. You will cause a riot by removing the 'free' NHS service.

Unlike common law (普通法) where judges have degree of flexibility to interpret the meaning of law, European law based on the civil law system where the freedom of judges to make interpretations are more limited.

According to wiki -

普通法系起源於英國，然後推廣於諸多使用英語的國家。「判例法」，即「普通法」，是普通法系的法律制度重要組成部分。相比之下，大陸法系更加依賴成文法典和法律、法規。

https://zh.wikipedia.org/zh-hk/%E8%8B%B1%E7%BE%8E%E6%B3%95%E7%B3%BB

so apparently uk could have limited the level of eu migration to a lower level by implementing existing eu rules on free movement and kick people out who can't get a job in like 3 months or something - the question is which UK government department will deal with this one? EEA nationals living in the UK do not need to register with any UK government department unless they want to work. Unlike in mainland Europe where any EEA nationals need to register with the local town hall, the UK does not operate such a civil household registration system (戶籍制度). Another important point is cost - who is going to pay for it all? Local government or Central government?

kick people out who can't get a job in like 3 months or something - these people will just come back in the next LCC flight!

The UK benefit and health service system differs from most mainland EU countries. The Labour welfare and health service reforms after 1945 were influenced by the Beveridge Report which suggested a cradle to grave social security system in the UK after WW2.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/bitesize/intermediate2/history/cradle_to_the_grave/welfare_state/revision/1/

The Labour reforms post 1945 were based on -

1) free at the point of need
2) universal provision for all
3) comprehensive in that it covers all types of need.

uk can also impose extra rules like other countries on claiming benefits but they didn't do that either for some weird reasons - since EU law does not allow member states to discriminate other EEA nationals within the country, thus the post 1945 UK welfare state needs to treat UK and EEA nationals equally. If it is universal (like child benefit) for British Citizens in the UK, it also needs to be universal for EEA nationals in the UK. This means that for example, the UK NHS cannot charge EEA patients unless it also charges British Citizens for health care. The post war welfare state is so sacred in the UK that even Mrs T was unable to move it towards the insurance system that most European countries operate in. You will cause a riot by removing the 'free' NHS service.

Unlike common law (普通法) where judges have degree of flexibility to interpret the meaning of law, European law based on the civil law system where the freedom of judges to make interpretations are more limited.

普通法系起源於英國，然後推廣於諸多使用英語的國家。「判例法」，即「普通法」，是普通法系的法律制度重要組成部分。相比之下，大陸法系更加依賴成文法典和法律、法規。

https://zh.wikipedia.org/zh-hk/%E8%8B%B1%E7%BE%8E%E6%B3%95%E7%B3%BB

The 450 days in 5 years and 90 days in the last year requirements are outlined in subsections 4(2) (a) and (b) of the British Nationality Act 1981. The Home Secretary can ignore subsections 4(2)(a) & (b) under subsection 4(4)(a) of the same Act -

treat the person to whom the application relates as fulfilling the requirement specified in subsection (2)(a) or subsection (2)(b), or both, although the number of days on which he was absent from the United Kingdom in the period there mentioned exceeds the number there mentioned

So if your rotation outside of the UK is 'Crown Service', then I would think the Home Office can ignore your absent from the UK for that rotation.

Is there any consecutive rules? As one of my rotation is with federal reserve...


https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/641989/nationality_procedures_levels_of_decision_making_v3_0.pdf

You can have a quick look at the above. If you are a BN(O) passport holder wishing to register to become a British Citizen under section 4(2) of the British Nationality Act 1981, then an Administrative Officer (AO) in the Home Office can exercise discretion for absents up to 900 days in 5 years and 180 days in the last year.

On the other hand, if you wish to naturalise to become a British Citizen using your HKSAR passport, the level of decision is higher. A Home Office AO can only exercise discretion for absents up to 730 days in 5 years and 180 days in the last year.

Civil Service Administrative Officers are the front line staff at government departments.

https://nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk/job-profiles/civil-service-administrative-officer

If your absences from the UK are due to the fact that you, as a career civil servant, are posted out of the UK by the UK government, then I would think staff at the Home Office will be likely to exercise discretion in your favour.

Yes and No - it is true that Malaysia does not allow dual nationality. This means that any Malaysian who become a British Citizen will lose his/her Malaysian citizenship.

However, she can apply for British Citizenship and then get a certificate of entitlement on her Malaysian passport instead of getting a British Citizen passport to show that she has the right of abode in the UK.

Two differences -

1) Holders of a passport with Certificate of Entitlement can use the British Citizen passport counters when entering the UK.

2) British Citizen status will not be lost even after prolong absents from the UK, while ILR can be lost after absences from the UK for more than 2 years.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39099574

Local government 唔於civil servants?


All civil servants are required to obey the Official Secrets Acts. In section 1(3) of the Official Secrets Act 1989, it stated that -

A person who is or has been a Crown servant or government contractor is guilty of an offence if without lawful authority he makes a damaging disclosure of any information, document or other article relating to security or intelligence which is or has been in his possession by virtue of his position as such but otherwise than as mentioned in subsection (1) above.

In section 12(1)(c) of the 1989 Act, one of the definition of a 'Crown servant' is -

any person employed in the civil service of the Crown, including Her Majesty’s Diplomatic Service, Her Majesty’s Overseas Civil Service, the civil service of Northern Ireland and the Northern Ireland Court Service

想問下有無人原本拎BNO過去，然後住5年直接升級BC ?
坊間話呢個係隱藏版upgrade BC。
但我自己查例好似要先申請到ILR先.....有錯請指教🙏🏻


You will need ILR before getting British Citizenship.

The only 隱藏版upgrade BC is for a BN(O) passport holder, to join the British Armed Forces as a Commonwealth citizen. Once you have served in the British Armed Forces for four years, you can get ILR (UK immigration rule 276O)

Requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as a foreign or Commonwealth citizen discharged from HM Forces

276O. The requirements for indefinite leave to remain in the United Kingdom as a foreign or Commonwealth citizen discharged from HM Forces are that the applicant:

(i) has completed at least four years’ service with HM Forces; and

(ii) was discharged from HM Forces on completion of engagement; and

(iii) was not discharged from HM Forces more than 2 years prior to the date on which the application is made unless they are applying following a grant of limited leavebto remain under paragraph 276QA; and

(iv) is not in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where paragraph 39E of these Rules applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded; and

(v) does not fall for refusal under the general grounds for refusal.

https://www.gov.uk/guidance/immigration-rules/immigration-rules-part-7-other-categories#pt7hmforces

You cannot joined the British Armed Forces if you only hold a HKSAR passport.
